Sentence: The grandfather clock blared across the hall. Bertha turned to the other side of the plush bed. It had been days since she bought the house, though it wasn't from her money. They had a deal, a deal she could not resist. Shifting the blankets over her head, she sighed—another mistake. A few months ago...

She was face to face with the Bargainer. Still in the black mourning clothes she used to mourn her dead husband, still wearing the single tear that graced her cheek, so singular, so perfect like a drop of blood. They were seated in their mansion—her mansion now. Minimalistic, very unlike her. It was her late husband who preferred it.
"Bertha..." He called her so sweetly, even on his deathbed. There she was, making a deal with the Bargainer. It was all worth it. She thought, the castle is in the memory of her husband.
Tick. Tick. Tick. Getting up from the bed, her black eyes drifted over to the grand window. The sky was still dark; it was still midnight.

Slipping on her slippers, she strolled to the balcony, opening the doors, letting the cool breeze grace her skin. 'The moon seems lovely tonight,' she thought. There were still some lights on in the castle. Of course there was—there were maintainers and workers who worked to keep the castle clean.

The rose garden was well manicured, looking exceptionally beautiful under the moonlight. Oh how she wished to visit them at this hour. Not because she was restricted—for this was already her property—but because she was too lazy to take the stairs, those things were torture. She sighed and went inside. On one of the many luxurious drawers in the chiffonier, she drew one out and picked a cigar, lighting it.

It was nice being alone, but not too nice. She still missed her husband, though he was now six feet under the soil. He was the only one who saw her, but even at that he still struggled to find the depths under those dark eyes. She wasn't pretty; she wasn't docile and loving like her name. She was like a rose, with only thorns and sharp leaves for petals.
This was going to be a long night… The Montante castle stood in the midst of dense foliage. It was an old and little-known castle, built by a nobleman hundreds of years ago.

Who knew it? She had no interest in knowing—all she knew was that it was hers. The papers and everything were signed under her name, with her own signature. But she didn't plan on staying there forever, no, it was too much of a hassle to get from the stairs. She just wanted to stay low for the time being.

The bathroom was very modest, almost too modest considering the grandness of the Master's Bedroom. The tub was made of porcelain, smooth, fair, devoid of any extra designs—much to her displeasure. After taking her bath, she put on her clothes and walked downstairs to the dining hall. The clinking of tableware increased her hunger. She then sat at the head of the long table. Breakfast was served at the table just for her... Only her.

It was more of a feast—the more she looked, the more she was in disbelief. The whole extensive wooden dining table was filled to the brim with food. It seemed that this was what they had been working on, even through the night.

Digging her fork into the tender mutton, she took a bite and asked: "Surely I can't finish all this, why did you cook so much?" Her black eyes drifted to the person beside her, clad in pristine white chef's robes, looking like she was eating his masterpiece.

"Madam, it has always been a custom of the Montante—the first meal is served to the Master, the rest of it is then distributed to the workers of the castle." He said it with a slight smile, his eyes still staring at the tender mutton she had eaten half of.

"The last owners of this castle, who were they?" she muttered. Chef Guijan replied, his voice low but clear. "The last master was the Trueblood descendant of the noble Montante, Master Lucas. The estate was sold years ago in exchange for more properties."
Chef Guijan was a stout old man, easy to temper as he was easy to flatter. His robes were pristine and his placements were even more precise. He came along with the castle.
"Seems reasonable." She nodded and dismissed him, then ate for a little while and left the dining hall, but not without passing the chef who stood at the door the whole time.

"Enjoy." It was a very long distance from the Montante Castle to any form of civilization. It was frustrating in many ways. The Bargainer was here. With the same mask on his face, smooth and lifelike, devoid of any color except the color he always wore, and she always liked—black. Not a sliver of his skin was exposed.

Standing hunched because of his very large height, he looked like something from children's nightmares and something found in the Grimm brothers' folktales. His voice was very low, almost akin to the sound of vibrating air.

"I see you've made yourself comfortable," he murmured through the mask. Bertha nodded, feeling slightly pleased. The castle was bigger than she had ever expected, but the thing was—what was the catch? She paid no money, nor property to gain such a fortune. She was skeptical as the masked one came to her in her home with a deal with an open condition. It seemed to be something of dreams... or nightmares.

Now it was 3:35 pm in the office of her boutique. She had just sorted some files before she heard he had arrived, and she welcomed him as quickly as she heard. Now they were seated in the cool office, the AC blasting cold air into the room despite the already cold weather.
"The castle... what are your conditions?" she finally spoke. It wouldn't be a lie to say her heart beat faster whenever he was with her, because true to his name, he brought Bertha her wealth.
"So eager now are we?" The Bargainer chuckled. There was silence between them.

The sun was low in the sky; it would soon be time to close her boutique. She placed the files on her desk and leaned in. "It would be strange if there wasn't a catch." She smirked. Her legs bounced impatiently.
He stood up, his cane sounding against the tiled floor. "Very well. We will meet by dusk."

"Bertha my dear..." Dominic didn't need to say more. She lifted the thick blankets to cover their bodies. Bertha hated the heat, but she couldn't let him go, not at this time. Slipping her hands around his thin waist, she lightly scolded behind him. "Go to sleep, it's already late. You have your appointment in the morning."

Dominic chuckled underneath his breath, each huff more silent than the last. "I'm soon to die... There's no need for appointments. They're all just after my money... Nothing else." Bertha's hand tightened slightly. She could feel him rubbing her hand with soft yet smooth fingers. This young master had never lifted a finger to do hard work. It was a pity.
"How are you sure I'm not after your money?" He sighed.
"Then you would have stopped giving me my drugs four years ago... Cough... You would have stopped taking care of me the night we were married." He spoke, his deep voice soothing as midnight rain.
"You—" "I don't have many days left, Bertha... I just want to die happy, in the arms of my wife, but... I don't want you to be too sad."

"I'm not sad." She snapped harshly, but her voice was little more than a whisper. "You're still too ignorant. All your property is now in my name." "Yes... And the children after you." "They won't be yours." "I know..."

Bertha held him tighter, burying her face in his thin back. It was a known fact for both of them. Dominic was infertile because of the drug for his ailment—or so they say. They tried all they could and eventually gave up. "Please say you love me..." He said.
"Please..." The rose garden was the first thing about the castle she loved. It was well maintained, cared for with utmost attention. It was dusk... The dying orange-pink hues graced the sky.

Standing in the midst of roses, she sighed, feeling the breeze on her skin. She owned this... all of this. She had lands and properties—assets that could move an entire state. She could have everything at her feet. All thanks to the Bargainer.

Clad in pristine clothing—sharp, black, yet comfortable—she turned to the Bargainer who stood hunched beside her, his cane firm on the soil, his shadow from the dying sun larger than life. "Here you are... At the top of the world." He began. He started tapping his cane in a slow rhythm. "Remember the first time we met?"
She could remember it fully. Fried blonde hair, melted makeup, gaudy clothes, drowning in the rain—she was being chased from the street where she did business.
Bertha was an empty husk. Devoid of light in those black, beautiful eyes. The rain fell heavier than ever, each drop hitting against her skin like stones, fueling her hatred.

Just when she contemplated committing atrocities, she felt the rain had stopped. Lifting her smeared face from her knees, her red eyes drifted to the shadow beside her. It was large, too large to be normal. Following the dark clothes, her eyes met a mask. A black velvet mask with no shape, no contour. Oval.
"Pretty girls shouldn't be out in the rain." It said. Its voice clear amidst the downpour. She eyed him with her brow raised and chuckled, not that it was funny. She had finally lost her mind.

"Aren't you a lovely thing." She laughed, leaning against the wall for support before lifting herself off the ground. Now standing, she was fully aware of how tall the creature was. She was quite tall herself, being 5'11", but she felt like a child facing the monstrosity.

"You want a free night? Well, beat it. I quit." She hissed and threw spit onto the rainy ground. The stranger just stared through the mask as if watching her behavior. They were still under the large black umbrella. It looked expensive, same as his attire and the long cane which he held in his left hand, supporting his crouch.

Just as she was about to leave, she heard his voice. "I can get you everything you desire." The alley was silent, so silent she heard her own breath. Everything she desired? Recalling those memories was painful, considering what she did to get to the top, the things she sacrificed.

The Bargainer had stayed true to his word, giving her everything she had wanted. Now she was in the beautiful garden of her own estate, talking to the same Bargainer, but the situation was different yet the same. A condition must be met.
"Nothing in this world comes free." She muttered. The sun had already set. They had been standing for thirty minutes. "Ever wondered about the cycle of the sun?" He questioned. She glanced at him.

"It is already predestined. Rises by dawn, falls by dusk." It was how it worked; it was just the order. The Bargainer nodded in approval. "Still the same. No matter the centuries, the millennia that passed. The human life is too short, but each lifetime starts with dawn and ends with dusk."
"Dusk." "Yes, I'm afraid your dusk is coming. Be prepared." Her heart beat loudly against her chest. Shifting back, she glared at the Bargainer. How could she not understand what he was saying?
"Watch your words..." Bertha hissed through gritted teeth. How could that be? It was just too soon. If she left, who would inherit all this? All the wealth she had accumulated over the years?

The Bargainer chuckled as soon as he heard her words. People always seemed to forget where they came from after tasting wealth. It was still the same, regardless of the time that passed. Centuries? Millennia? It didn't matter.

"My words have never changed. You asked for the condition and I laid it. Enjoy the time you have left." He planted his cane down, stopping the rhythm that had been going on, the rhythm Bertha had grown to fear.

She watched as he went away, slowly as he came. Shutting her eyes, she took a deep breath, trying to calm herself. Bertha couldn't sleep that night. She was still in the rose garden, still in her work clothes. Her dark eyes gazed through the woods under the moonlight.

Sitting on a stone pavement, she was in deep thought. She didn't want to die. She wanted to live. She was only 28. Puffing the cigar from her nose, she ruffled her black hair. She needed a plan. She needed to leave the country, the continent if need be, so they wouldn't find her.

Alone in the rose garden, she contemplated the identity of the Bargainer. She had never seen his face underneath that mask. Never seen him anywhere else except when he came to meet her. His entire existence was a mystery to her.

Since that night under the rain, her life had changed. She had been a prostitute, wasted goods. She had been robbed and beaten that night. Being the least beautiful among the girls in the same profession, she had been the least favored.
She got everything she wanted in the end. Revenge? She paid them back every coin. Properties and assets? She got them through her late husband. This magnificent castle? She got it.
But it didn't come without a price, as she had thought. The price was too much. She valued her life, her goods.

Lifting herself off the stone pavement, she strolled back into the castle. She had a plan in mind, and she would see it through to the end. She would not die like this. She would prevent her dusk from happening.

Bertha had always been the bitter child. Even as a little girl at the orphanage, everyone knew her with a frown on her little face. That nature grew with her and cost her many things. Ungrateful, greedy, selfish... Those were the words that followed her into adulthood, the words she built around herself as a fortress.

Kicked out of the orphanage because she was too old to stay and be adopted, she tried many ways of living. She dropped out of secondary school and began working as a cleaner behind bars. Nobody wanted to see her face; they said it would scare the customers away.

She was eventually kicked out because of her attitude, her nonchalance. Roaming the streets, she was caught in a series of unfortunate events before ultimately staying on the road, looking for anyone who would trade money for her body. She fried her black hair blonde, put on the heaviest makeup, wore the lightest clothes—even in cold weather.

There was nothing she wouldn't do for money. And then, at her lowest, the Bargainer came. Offered a deal too good to resist, and gave her a life too good to be true. Well, almost too good. Now, sitting at her chiffonier, cleaning her face, she looked at her features once again. Low cheekbones, thin lips, eyes larger than their sockets. She was less than beautiful, far less.
Yet Dominic saw her... treasured her, even knowing what she was truly after. He was the only one in a long, very long time who called her name with tenderness. "Bertha..." Please say you love me...

Those were his last words. Young master Dominic Von Aine, the sickly man who had the world at his feet, had pleaded with a former prostitute. Was he happy and healthy in heaven? She wouldn't know, because she was going to hell.

Applying her red lipstick, she stood up, walked with her luggage, placing her black hat perfectly on her head, not a millimeter wrong. She didn't allow any help carrying her luggage as she wheeled it herself down the steps. The servants lined up, all neat and perfect.

The hangar wasn't too far away, but too far to walk. Entering the sleek black car, she drove to the castle's hangar. There weren't any jets there because they would occupy too much space. Most of the helicopters were hers. Offloading her luggage, she sat in the back seat. The pilots were on standby, and soon they were in the air.

The view of the castle was magnificent. It stretched far and wide. It was such a pity that castle came with her life. Coming back to the Von Aine mansion wasn't her intention. Not that she despised her ended marriage—no; it was seemingly worse than that. The mansion was well maintained, beautiful, yet still minimalistic. It was many times smaller than the Montante castle, but it was where she had spent the last five years.

How did she get into marriage with Dominic? It wasn't like some typical maid-cleaning-story cliché. She came in full force and demanded marriage. He had made a deal with the Bargainer to take care of some people who were after his money. That was when she knew he wasn't as innocent as his first impression—sitting in the garden, wearing light clothes with a smile as he watched the butterflies.

He was her contract. He knew he wouldn't live long. According to him, it was a miracle he'd lived this long. When she asked about his relatives on their wedding day—as no one came to the simple yet lavish hall except for housekeepers and his medical help—he replied:

"You are my only family, dear..." And they married. Lived for five years before his body failed him and he passed away. She fortified the mansion, hiring the best bodyguards she could lay her hands on. She could never forget the Bargainer's words.

Her dusk was coming. Taking a deep breath, she caressed the framed picture in her hand. It was Dominic as a child—slightly healthier, but still paler than normal. His lifelong disease had marked him young.

The mansion stood in perfect order, every photo, every vase preserved as on the day he died. "Madam." A voice called from behind. Her black eyes drifted to the doorway. The head bodyguard stood waiting. "Any problems?" she asked.
"No, ma'am. Everyone is on guard.”. "Good." The guard left. Alone again, she noticed how much warmer this room felt than the castle, despite its sparse furnishings.

The sun set faster than Bertha expected. In her study, her hands gripped the chair arms until her knuckles threatened to split. The air hung thick despite the purifier humming in the corner. Dark bruises shadowed her eyes—two nights without sleep.

She shouldn't have made that deal. Should have stopped when she had everything. But she'd traded sanity for wealth, empathy for power... even her womb for this gilded cage. Now he wanted her life? Rising abruptly, she lit a cigar from her desk drawer and stalked to the window. The sun bled out, orange and pink fading to bruised purple.

"Where would I be?" she murmured, laughing bitterly as she tapped ash onto the floor. The smoke curled from her lips with her sigh. "Doesn't matter anyway." A voice answered from the darkness behind her.

"I'm afraid you're correct." That sound—low, ancient, terrifyingly familiar—stopped her heart mid-beat. She turned. There. Behind the desk. The towering figure with his cane. His mask still velvet... but now the color of fresh blood.
"How did you get here?" She stepped back, fingers digging into the window frame. His cane tapped that same dreadful rhythm from the rose garden. "Same as always. I walked."

"Don't feed me that nonsense." Her voice sliced cold through the room, though the slightest tremor betrayed her. The Bargainer laughed. "Bertha. Bertha. Bertha." Three summons, each heavier than the last.

"You knew the rules when we made our deal. Nothing comes free." "Then take your damned castle back. I revoke it." She lifted her chin defiantly. The tapping ceased. Gloved fingers slid into his coat pocket, withdrawing a small, weathered book—The Ledger. Its cracked spine whispered of countless deals. He flipped slowly to a page bearing her maiden name: Bertha Onman Skodd. Her signature glared up in faded ink.

Beneath it, terms and conditions sprawled in meticulous crimson script—words she'd never bothered to read, the handwriting too ornate, the clauses too dense. "You can't run from a deal, dear Bertha. That's not how the order works." His mask gleamed wetly in the lamplight. Her nails bit into the wooden frame as her black-rimmed eyes searched for any weakness.

"So this is it?" Her voice echoed strangely in the silent study. Not a pin drop from the guards outside. Where were they? "My fate?" "Predestined the moment you signed." He closed the ledger with a snap, smoothing his coat as he tucked it away. "Then why not state your price up front? You call yourself a merchant, but you're just a scammer."

Silence. Then—a rumble from deep in his throat. A laugh that turned her blood to ice. "Scammer?" His grip tightened on the cane until the leather creaked. "I've walked this world long enough to hear every insult. But this I know: I am what I am. Every deal has terms. Every secret carries a price. You know my secret, Bertha—that I exist. And that knowledge... demands payment."

Her hand flashed up. A silver pistol gleamed between them—the one she'd ordered for protection. The barrel wavered slightly despite her iron grip. "One more word," she hissed, "and I'll put a bullet through that mask."

The Bargainer laughed again. "How humans cling to their worthless lives." He stepped closer, cane thudding against the floorboards. Bertha retreated until the window frame pressed into her back. Her black eyes locked onto his advancing form. She pulled the trigger. The bullet went straight to the Bargainer's neck. Her eyes widened, her breath came in cold gasps.

The terrifying truth revealed itself. No blood. No wound. The bullet flattened against his skin like a pellet, falling harmlessly to the floor. She shot many more and they all fell off, not a single one affecting him. With the last bullet, she aimed at the center of his forehead. It punched a hole through the velvet mask, lodging there.

Unharmed, the tall creature plucked the bullet out and threw it to the floor. His hands moved to the back of his head. "Ever wondered how I got my wealth? How long I've lived, what I am?" Metallic clicks echoed from the back of his skull. To her horror, the velvet oval mask clattered to the floor. Revealing his face... Or if it could be called a face.

Bertha recoiled, eyes bulging with primal terror. Mask or no mask—it changed nothing. The face beneath was a blank, oval expanse. No eyes. No nose. No mouth. Nothing. Just scaly, corpse-pale skin stretched tight over nothingness. His voice vibrated from the void. "Curiosity, dread... fear. This is what you feel." A laugh scraped the air, making her shiver in disgust.

"How are you talking?" Her voice was a strangled whisper. He shrugged off his coat, revealing tattered fabric revealed under this fanciness. She covered her mouth, stifling a scream. His body was a nightmare tapestry. Countless eyes, countless noses and mouths littered his torso and limbs like obscene growths. The eyes, as soulless as they were, stared at her. Disgusting her... inviting her. His limbs elongated unnaturally, thin and impossibly long.

Like a flash of shadow, he appeared in front of her. Cold, spidery fingers clamped her jaw. "It's so sad to see you go..." Tick. Tick. Tick. Her heart hammered against her ribs like a trapped bird. She could see her life flash before her tear-blurred eyes. Tears welled up and fell. The kohl she wore blackened the tears, making her look even uglier than she felt. His grip tightened.

Crack. Agony exploded through her shattered jaw. "I've seen empires fall, revolutions rise and it's all the same." A jagged dagger appeared in his other hand – beautiful, cruel. Who knew how many lives it had taken? With a wet thunk, it plunged deep within her ribcage. Her scream tore through the silence.

"You humans follow the same repetitive fashion..." He ripped the blade free and plunged it again. And again. Her screams weakened to gurgles. Bertha looked at him, her eyes full-blown in fear and pain, red streaks visible. Blood pooled thick and dark between them.
This was it... She was dying. "Every dawn has its dusk." His hand, slick with her blood, plunged into her ruined chest. She convulsed, staring into his faceless void.

"Each secret demands a price." His fingers closed. Riiip. Her heart tore free. Her body dropped to the floor. Silent. Lifeless. Dead. He raised the dripping heart towards the back of his head. A wet, tearing sound filled the room. A giant, jagged-toothed maw split open amidst the stolen faces, feasting greedily.
Bertha was dead. The light gone. Was it mercy, not seeing that final horror? You wouldn't know. You're too busy reading this book. Tick. Tick. Tick.
